update.description:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue [#946](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges)).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.
update.title: Fix GpuRaySensor vertical rays

content.raw: No, not necessarily. But I kept it in there to indicate that this is still a ratio of horiz and vert samples. Would you prefer to have it removed?
content.html: No, not necessarily. But I kept it in there to indicate that this is still a ratio of horiz and vert samples. Would you prefer to have it removed?

content.raw: Yes, that's intended. The vertical half angle is the center of vfov, i.e. 0 when angles are symmetric.
content.html: Yes, that's intended. The vertical half angle is the center of vfov, i.e. 0 when angles are symmetric.

content.raw: Yes, exactly. If the angles are asymmetric and the vertical half angle of the laser ray fov is not 0, then we need to make the camera vfov bigger in order to cover all laser ray fov but still be horizontally.
content.html: Yes, exactly. If the angles are asymmetric and the vertical half angle of the laser ray fov is not 0, then we need to make the camera vfov bigger in order to cover all laser ray fov but still be horizontally.

content.raw: when is padding needed? only for asymmetric angles?
content.html: when is padding needed? only for asymmetric angles?

content.raw: for symmetric vertical angles, this will always evaluate to 0, is this intended? e.g. \(0.3 \+ -0.3\) /2 = 0
content.html: for symmetric vertical angles, this will always evaluate to 0, is this intended? e.g. (0.3 + -0.3) /2 = 0

content.raw: do you need to divide by 1 here?
content.html: do you need to divide by 1 here?

content.raw: our code checker picked up a couple style errors here. Could you add a space after `//`?
content.html: our code checker picked up a couple style errors here. Could you add a space after //?

content.raw:
I tested on OS X and get `gpu_laser` integration test failure there. This is the result I’m getting:

![gpulaser\_osx.jpg](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4101969781-gpulaser_osx.jpg 'gpulaser\_osx.jpg')

The laser penetrates the ground plane and the ray intersections near the bottom of the box are also a little off.

content.raw:
I can't share the actual SDF but when taking the screen shot above I was just using two arbitrary angles for testing, that was not related to any real existing sensor. In fact, I only found that bug now because most of the time I tested with settings for the Velodyne VLP-16, i.e. symmetrical -15° to +15°. It's very similar to https://bitbucket.org/DataspeedInc/velodyne_simulator/src/master/velodyne_description/urdf/VLP-16.urdf.xacro

I'm on vacation for the next week, so I won't be able to work on this now. I would also vote for more tests but personally I would prefer them to be added in a seperate PR. 
I think the most common sensor types should be working now and even if we may find more bugs it's probably already much more usable than the current GpuRaySensor.
content.html:
I can't share the actual SDF but when taking the screen shot above I was just using two arbitrary angles for testing, that was not related to any real existing sensor. In fact, I only found that bug now because most of the time I tested with settings for the Velodyne VLP-16, i.e. symmetrical -15° to +15°. It's very similar to https://bitbucket.org/DataspeedInc/velodyne_simulator/src/master/velodyne_description/urdf/VLP-16.urdf.xacro

I'm on vacation for the next week, so I won't be able to work on this now. I would also vote for more tests but personally I would prefer them to be added in a seperate PR. I think the most common sensor types should be working now and even if we may find more bugs it's probably already much more usable than the current GpuRaySensor.

content.raw:
It is looking good. Just in case, can you share the SDF for the Velodyne sensor that you are using? I do feel that yours is from -10° to -30°, is that possible? Besides that I made two very small comments and I think we can approve this PR. 2048 for minimal value seems a little big, but 1048 didn’t look very good, so I understand your decision and I think it is ok, from my side.  
  
I feel that we should add more tests to cover more cases as the one you pointed out and fixed, with different values of VFOV. If you want to do it that is great, I offer myself to add them in a separated PR later if not. What is your opinion @iche033?
content.html:
It is looking good. Just in case, can you share the SDF for the Velodyne sensor that you are using? I do feel that yours is from -10° to -30°, is that possible? Besides that I made two very small comments and I think we can approve this PR. 2048 for minimal value seems a little big, but 1048 didn’t look very good, so I understand your decision and I think it is ok, from my side.

I feel that we should add more tests to cover more cases as the one you pointed out and fixed, with different values of VFOV. If you want to do it that is great, I offer myself to add them in a separated PR later if not. What is your opinion @iche033?

content.raw: Use  this->CosHorzFOV\(\)\` instead of this->chfov\`.
content.html: Use this->CosHorzFOV()` instead of this->chfov`.

content.raw: Why you are not using  ``this->CosHorzFOV()` `` instead of ``this->chfov`?``
content.html: Why you are not using this->CosHorzFOV()` instead of this->chfov`?

content.html: Thanks Jacob, it is looking good! I will test it and also review the PR.

content.raw:
Today I discovered a bug: The plugin only worked correctly when vertical min and max angles where symmetrical (i.e. vertical half angle = 0). But I was able to fix it so that now it should also be possible to create sensors with asymmetric angles like this:

![Unsymmetrix_angles_fix_small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/269611420-Unsymmetrix_angles_fix_small.png)

This matters for example when simulating Velodyne HDL-32E which has +10° to -30° FOV.

Please feel free to also test this behaviour, mistakes are always possible...
content.html:
Today I discovered a bug: The plugin only worked correctly when vertical min and max angles where symmetrical (i.e. vertical half angle = 0). But I was able to fix it so that now it should also be possible to create sensors with asymmetric angles like this:

This matters for example when simulating Velodyne HDL-32E which has +10° to -30° FOV.

Please feel free to also test this behaviour, mistakes are always possible...

update.description:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue [#946](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges)).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.
update.title: Fix GpuRaySensor vertical rays

content.raw: I now implemented a simple solution that ensures a minimum horizontal resolution of 2048 pixels per camera/texture (vertical resolution is set accordingly). I think that should be safe regarding the GPU's max. texture size. Of course one could exceed this 2048 by setting a higher sample count, but I think that’s unlikely for now. And I think the results are "good enough" or do you think it's a too low resolution?
content.html: I now implemented a simple solution that ensures a minimum horizontal resolution of 2048 pixels per camera/texture (vertical resolution is set accordingly). I think that should be safe regarding the GPU's max. texture size. Of course one could exceed this 2048 by setting a higher sample count, but I think that’s unlikely for now. And I think the results are "good enough" or do you think it's a too low resolution?

update.description:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue [#946](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges)).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.
update.title: Fix GpuRaySensor vertical rays

content.raw: I'm not yet sure which solution for the resolution I'd prefer. I mean, at least for me the motivation of switching to GPU laser is to have better performance when simulating robots with not only one but multiple LIDARs on board. So I think the resolution should be as high as needed but not higher.
content.html: I'm not yet sure which solution for the resolution I'd prefer. I mean, at least for me the motivation of switching to GPU laser is to have better performance when simulating robots with not only one but multiple LIDARs on board. So I think the resolution should be as high as needed but not higher.
